2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Of course it is, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > DAVOS < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The guards marched Davos Seaworth across a bridge of black basalt and under an iron portcullis showing signs of rust.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos stumbled across a muddy yard with his hands bound at the wrists.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos did the same, fumbling at the clasp with his bound hands.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos could hear the rain lashing at the walls, and a steady dripping where the roof had sprung a leak.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos waited wet and dripping, his wrists chafing where the wet rope dug into his skin.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > One, two, three, four, < / emphasis > Davos counted, before the thunder came.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos had heard that some of the lords of the Three Sisters had webbed hands and feet, but he had always put that down as just another sailors story.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAs he jerked up his captives maimed left hand the lightning flashed again, throwing the shadow of Davos Seaworths shortened fingers across the blunt and brutal face of Godric Borrell, Lord of Sweetsister. Any man can steal a ribbon, the lord said, but those fingers do not lie.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I have been called that, my lord. Davos was a lord himself, and had been a knight for long years now, but deep down he was still what he had always been, a smuggler of common birth who had bought his knighthood with a hold of onions and salt fish. I have been called worse things too. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Only if Stannis is a king. The lord weighed him with hard black eyes. Most knights who land upon my shores seek me in my hall, not in the Belly of the Whale.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos remembered it well from his smuggling days.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > A kings command and a friends betrayal, < / emphasis > Davos might have said.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf half of them were still afloat, Davos would be shocked.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Salladhor the Beggar, thats what your king has made me, Salladhor Saan complained to Davos, as the remnants of his fleet limped across the Bite. Salladhor the Smashed.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd my gold, where is all the gold that I was promised? When Davos had tried to assure him that he would have his payment, Salla had erupted. When, < emphasis > when < / emphasis >?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos had tried to persuade him to stay true.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf Salla abandoned Stannis and his cause, he pointed out, he abandoned all hope of collecting the gold that was due him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileA victorious King Tommen was not like to pay his defeated uncles debts, after all.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSallas only hope was to remain loyal to Stannis Baratheon until he won the Iron Throne.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Perhaps some lord with honey on his tongue might have swayed the Lysene pirate prince, but Davos was an onion knight, and his words had only provoked Salla to fresh outrage. On Dragonstone I was patient, he said, when the red woman burned wooden gods and screaming men.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > I knew the day would come, < / emphasis > Davos told himself.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Delivered to you by a friend, < / emphasis > Davos thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > My lord, said Davos, if you would send me on to White Harbor, His Grace would count it as an act of friendship. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Davos feared the worst.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Lord Sunderland is sworn to the Eyrie, Davos said. By rights he should deliver me to Lady Arryn. He would stand a better chance with her than with the Lannisters, he judged.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThough she had taken no part in the War of the Five Kings, Lysa Arryn was a daughter of Riverrun, and aunt to the Young Wolf.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Littlefinger rules the Vale now.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhere are the pirates? When Davos did not answer, he rapped his spoon against the table. The Lyseni.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSoon or late the world would learn that Salladhor Saan had abandoned Stannis Baratheon, leaving him without a fleet, but they would not hear it from the lips of Davos Seaworth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe Lyseni would gladly have taken him south with him, he avowed, but Davos had refused.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis needed Wyman Manderly, and had trusted Davos to win him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I have never had a Kings Hand beneath my roof before, Lord Godric said. Would Stannis ransom you, I wonder? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Stannis had given Davos lands and titles and offices, but would he pay good gold to buy back his life?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The Imp? Davos did not understand the question. He is at Kings Landing, condemned to die for the murder of his nephew. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos struggled to believe what he was hearing. You are telling me that Tywin Lannister is dead? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Lord Tywin dead.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIll not have it said that I gave Stannis aid and counsel.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos spooned it up gratefully.
2016-07-07 00:50fileA spider crab was embroidered there, white on a grey-green field. We heard tales that Stannis burned his Hand. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Melisandre had given Alester Florent to her god on Dragonstone, to conjure up the wind that bore them north.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos had misliked that wind.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Davos saw her hand, he stared.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNot the one who makes the stew. He tore the bread apart and offered half to Davos. Eat.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > It was, though any stale crust would have tasted just as fine to Davos; it meant he was a guest here, for this one night at least.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > I will see the dawn, at least, < / emphasis > Davos told himself.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos had only tasted it once before, when King Robert had sent a half a fish to him at a feast on Dragonstone.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHe still had all his teeth, Davos saw, though most of them were yellow and one on the top was black and dead. She was making for Braavos, but a gale swept her into the Bite and she smashed up against some of my rocks.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Not as treacherous as men, < / emphasis > thought Davos.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe wolf king took their gold, but he gave them land and let them keep their gods. He mopped at his stew with a chunk of bread. If Stannis thinks the fat man will ride the stag, hes wrong.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Freys? That was the last thing that Davos would have expected. The Freys killed Lord Wymans son, we heard. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Rhaegar, < / emphasis > he named himself.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Wyman and Lord Walder have made a pact, and mean to seal it with a marriage. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos felt as though the lord had punched him in the belly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Stannis Baratheon had desperate need of White Harbor.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs for your King Stannis, when he was Roberts master of ships he sent a fleet into my port without my leave and made me hang a dozen fine friends.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Because he is your rightful king, < / emphasis > Davos thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The lion is dead, said Davos, slowly. Theres your truth, my lord.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTywin Lannister is dead. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileNot Tommen, he is just a child.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIs it Ser Kevan? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos understood.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNed Stark told my father that, here in this very hall. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe Mad King had sent to the Eyrie for Starks head, but Jon Arryn sent him back defiance.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon Snow, she named him, after Arryn.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMy father sat where I sit now when Lord Eddard came to Sisterton.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOur maester urged us to send Starks head to Aerys, to prove our loyalty.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe Mad King was open-handed with them as pleased him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBy then we knew that Jon Arryn had taken Gulltown, though.

2016-07-07 00:50fileRobert was the first man to gain the wall, and slew Marq Grafton with his own hand. This Baratheon is fearless, I said. He fights the way a king should fight. Our maester chuckled at me and told us that Prince Rhaegar was certain to defeat this rebel.

2016-07-07 00:50fileWe may lose our heads, its true but what if we prevail? My father sent him on his way with his head still on his shoulders. If you lose, he told Lord Eddard, you were never here. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > No more than I was, said Davos Seaworth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMance Rayder wore only a thin tunic that left his limbs naked to the cold.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > They could have let him keep his cloak, < / emphasis > Jon Snow thought, < emphasis > the one the wildling woman patched with strips of crimson silk.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Mance knows the haunted forest better than any ranger, Jon had told King Stannis, in his final effort to convince His Grace that the King-Beyond-the-Wall would be of more use to them alive than dead. He knows Tormund Giantsbane.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis had remained unmoved.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Beneath the weeping Wall, Lady Melisandre raised her pale white hands. <emphasis > We all must choose, < / emphasis > she proclaimed. Man or woman, young or old, lord or peasant, our choices are the same. Her voice made Jon Snow think of anise and nutmeg and cloves.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Mance Rayders thick grey-brown hair blew about his face as he walked.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMance was bloody when the queens men half-shoved, half-carried him to the cage.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Lady Melisandre watched him rise. <emphasis > FREE FOLK!
2016-07-07 00:50fileJoramun had died thousands of years ago, but Mance had found his grave beneath a glacier, high up in the Frostfangs.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Ygritte had told Jon that Mance never found the horn.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > She lied, or else Mance kept it secret even from his own.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The Horn of Joramun? Melisandre said. No.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe Lord of Light has seen his children in their peril and sent a champion to them, Azor Ahai reborn. She swept a hand toward Stannis, and the great ruby at her throat pulsed with light.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVal stood beside him, tall and fair.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThey had crowned her with a simple circlet of dark bronze, yet she looked more regal in bronze than Stannis did in gold.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Lady Melisandre wore no crown, but every man there knew that she was Stannis Baratheons real queen, not the homely woman he had left to shiver at Eastwatch-by-the-Sea.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTalk was, the king did not mean to send for Queen Selyse and their daughter until the Nightfort was ready for habitation.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon felt sorry for them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > cried Melisandre. Behold the fate of those who choose the darkness! < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Inside his cage, Mance Rayder clawed at the noose about his neck with bound hands and screamed incoherently of treachery and witchery, denying his kingship, denying his people, denying his name, denying all that he had ever been.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon watched unblinking.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon wanted them to take that fear with them to their new homes south of the Wall.
2016-07-07 00:50fileClutching the bars of his cage with bound hands, Mance sobbed and begged.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon found himself remembering a song.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Val stood on the platform as still as if she had been carved of salt.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon wondered what Ygritte would have done in her place.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > He found himself thinking about Sam and Maester Aemon, about Gilly and the babe.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Last night he had dreamed of Sam drowning, of Ygritte dying with his arrow in her (it had not been his arrow, but in his dreams it always was), of Gilly weeping tears of blood.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon Snow had seen enough. Now, he said.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGarth Greyfeather and Bearded Ben nocked shafts, bent their bows, loosed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > One arrow took Mance Rayder in the chest, one in the gut, one in the throat.
2016-07-07 00:50fileA womans sobs echoed off the Wall as the wildling king slid bonelessly to the floor of his cage, wreathed in fire. And now his Watch is done, Jon murmured softly.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMance Rayder had been a man of the Nights Watch once, before he changed his black cloak for one slashed with bright red silk.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Up on the platform, Stannis was scowling.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon refused to meet his eyes.

2016-07-07 00:50fileEvery time the fire licked upward, more branches tumbled free, cherry red and black. The Lord of Light made the sun and moon and stars to light our way, and gave us fire to keep the night at bay, Melisandre told the wildlings. None can withstand his flames. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stannis Baratheon drew Lightbringer.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had seen the show before but not like < emphasis > this, < / emphasis > never before like this.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Stannis raised the blade above his head, men had to turn their heads or cover their eyes.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Westeros has but one king, said Stannis.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon Snow raised his hand and lowered it, and his black ranks parted right and left, clearing a path to the Wall, where Dolorous Edd Tollett pushed open the iron gate.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Come, urged Melisandre. Come to the light or run back to the darkness. In the pit below her, the fire was crackling. If you choose life, come to me. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > If you would eat, come to me, < / emphasis > Jon thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Hesitant, wary of some trap, the first few prisoners edged across the planks and through the ring of the stakes, toward Melisandre and the Wall.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon flexed the fingers of his sword hand.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSo the new god devoured the corpse of the old, and cast gigantic shadows of Stannis and Melisandre upon the Wall, black against the ruddy red reflections on the ice.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNext came Rattleshirt in clattering armor made of bones and boiled leather, his helm a giants skull.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon did not believe for a moment that he would keep faith.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe wondered what Val was feeling as she watched him kneel, forgiven.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > It is too cold for this mummers show, < / emphasis > thought Jon. The free folk despise kneelers, he had warned Stannis. Let them keep their pride, and they will love you better. His Grace would not listen.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had detailed Horse and Satin and half a dozen others to lead them through the Wall with torches.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSoon or late, however, Tormund Giantsbane would assault the Wall again, and when that hour came Jon wondered whose side Stanniss new-made subjects would choose.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > You can give them land and mercy, but the free folk choose their own kings, and it was Mance they chose, not you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bowen Marsh edged his mount up next to Jons. This is a day I never thought to see. The Lord Steward had thinned notably since suffering a head wound at the Bridge of Skulls.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > He no longer looks much like a pomegranate, < / emphasis > Jon thought.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The realm will curse us all for this, declared Ser Alliser Thorne in a venomous tone. Every honest man in Westeros will turn his head and spit at the mention of the Nights Watch. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Quiet in the ranks. Ser Alliser had grown more circumspect since Lord Janos had lost his head, but the malice was still there.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had toyed with the idea of giving him the command Slynt had refused, but he wanted the man close.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Giving Mance Rayder to the fire did not change the truth of that.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon Snow could see his breath in the air.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Some shivering, some too numb to shiver, they listened as the kings voice rumbled off the Wall. You are free to go, Stannis told them. Tell your people what you witnessed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > cried Lady Melisandre.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Val did not join the chant, he saw.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon watched Stannis descend from the platform, with Melisandre by his side.

2016-07-07 00:50fileMoonlight shimmered on their armor and the wind whipped at their cloaks. Lord Steward, Jon told Marsh, break up that stockade for firewood and throw the corpses in the flames. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Once the free folk are settled in the Gift, they will become part of the realm, Jon pointed out. These are desperate days, and like to grow more desperate.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis is not wrong in this.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Common cause against a common foe, I could agree with that, said Bowen Marsh, but that does not mean we should allow tens of thousands of half-starved savages through the Wall.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Unlikely, said Bowen Marsh. These are not raiders, out to steal a wife and some plunder.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTormund will have old women with him, children, herds of sheep and goats, even < emphasis > mammoths.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon had climbed the Wall himself.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Mance Rayders host had broken against the Wall like a wave upon a stony shore, though the defenders were no more than a handful of old men, green boys, and cripples.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYet what Bowen was suggesting went against all of Jons instincts. If we seal the gates, we cannot send out rangers, he pointed out. We will be as good as blind. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Marsh hesitated. Lord Snow, I am not one to bear tales, but there has been talk that you are becoming too too friendly with Lord Stannis.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Janos Slynt might be gone, but his lies lingered. I know what they say. Jon had heard the whispers, had seen men turn away when he crossed the yard. What would they have me do, take up swords against Stannis and the wildlings both?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Lord Stannis helped us when we needed help, Marsh said doggedly, but he is still a rebel, and his cause is doomed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > It is not my intent to choose any side, said Jon, but I am not as certain of the outcome of this war as you seem to be, my lord.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNot with Lord Tywin dead. If the tales coming up the kingsroad could be believed, the Kings Hand had been murdered by his dwarf son whilst sitting on a privy.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had known Tyrion Lannister, briefly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A boy he may be, my lord, but King Robert was well loved, and most men still accept that Tommen is his son.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe more they see of Lord Stannis the less they love him, and fewer still are fond of Lady Melisandre with her fires and this grim red god of hers.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThose without wives complain twice as much about their lords. Jon Snow glanced toward the stockade.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTwo walls were down, a third falling fast. I will leave you to finish here, Bowen.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Smoke and drifting ash still lingered in the air about the pit as Jon trotted back to the gate.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDolorous Edd went before him with a torch.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Harmas dead, Jon said. But not the pigs.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > A cup of wine with Maester Aemon, some quiet words with Sam, a few laughs with Pyp and Grenn and Toad.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Aemon and Sam were gone, though, and his other friends I will take supper with the men this evening. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Boiled beef and beets. Dolorous Edd always seemed to know what was cooking. Hobb says hes out of horseradish, though.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Jon entered, four builders were playing at tiles at the table nearest the steps.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon Snow did not join the laughter. Making mock of another mans prayer is fools work, Pyp.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Lady Melisandre is not part of my command.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Pyp laid a hand on Toads arm. Croak no more, brave Toad, for our Great Lord Snow has spoken. Pyp hopped to his feet and gave Jon a mocking bow. I beg pardon.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon wanted to shake some sense into him. Waggle your ears all you like.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon wanted nothing more.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVal stood on the tower roof, gazing up at the Wall.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis kept her closely penned in rooms above his own, but he did allow her to walk the battlements for exercise.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > She looks lonely, < / emphasis > Jon thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Ygritte had been pretty in her own way, with her red hair kissed by fire, but it was her smile that made her face come alive.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVal did not need to smile; she would have turned mens heads in any court in the wide world.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Lonely and lovely and lethal, < / emphasis > Jon Snow reflected, < emphasis > and I might have had her.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon could hear the creak of chains as the winch cage swung and scraped against the ice.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He was walking beneath the shell of the Lord Commanders Tower, past the spot where Ygritte had died in his arms, when Ghost appeared beside him, his warm breath steaming in the cold.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAt Jons knock, he came shuffling, a taper in his hand, to open the door a crack. Do I intrude? asked Jon.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe only seemed young compared with Aemon.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Clydas poured, Jon held the cup with both hands, sniffed the spices, swallowed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs bright as the sun. Jon raised his cup. To Stannis Baratheon and his magic sword. The wine was bitter in his mouth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMany good men have been bad kings, Maester Aemon used to say, and some bad men have been good kings. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He would know. Aemon Targaryen had seen nine kings upon the Iron Throne.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe had been a kings son, a kings brother, a kings uncle. I looked at that book Maester Aemon left me.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > would be a fine thing on the Wall. Jon put aside his wine cup and drew on his black moleskin gloves. A pity that the sword that Stannis wields is cold.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGhost, with me. Jon Snow raised the hood of his cloak and pulled at the door.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon nodded to the guards before making his way past the silent racks of spears to his rooms.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGhost curled up on his rug and went to sleep, but Jon could not rest yet.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > My last friend, < / emphasis > Jon thought ruefully.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon rose and climbed the steps to the narrow bed that had once been Donal Noyes.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > DAENERYS < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > No, < emphasis > Khaleesi, < / emphasis > Irri murmured, it is your eunuch Grey Worm and the bald men.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Yes. Her hair was disheveled and her bedclothes all atangle, Dany realized. Help me dress.
2016-07-07 00:50fileI have no slaves. Dany did not understand. Why does she weep? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The rest she had from Skahaz, Reznak, and Grey Worm, when they were ushered into her presence.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDany knew their tidings were bad before a word was spoken.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Grey Worm answered. Your servants were set upon as they walked the bricks of Meereen to keep Your Graces peace.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Dany made a fist.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMissandei and her brothers had been taken from their home on Naath by raiders from the Basilisk Isles and sold into slavery in Astapor.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYoung as she was, Missandei had shown such a gift for tongues that the Good Masters had made a scribe of her.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Mercy, < / emphasis > thought Dany.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGrey Worm, pull your men back to their barracks.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Daenerys was sick unto death of Zhak and Merreq; she was sick of all the Mereenese, great and small alike. Let them go, but see that they take no more than the clothes upon their backs.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Yes, < / emphasis > Daenerys thought, < emphasis > and so am I. < / emphasis > We must keep them safe as well.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When she returned to her rooms atop the pyramid, she found Missandei crying softly on her pallet, trying as best she could to muffle the sound of her sobs. Come sleep with me, she told the little scribe. Dawn will not come for hours yet. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Your Grace is kind to this one. Missandei slipped under the sheets. He was a good brother. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Dany wrapped her arms about the girl. Tell me of him. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > As he loved you. Dany stroked the girls hair. Say the word, my sweet, and I will send you from this awful place.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > The word made Danys eyes fill up with tears. I want to keep you safe. Missandei was only a child.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWell, Ser Willem did, but then he died, and Viserys I want to protect you but it is so hard.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > mother, whispered Missandei. Mother to dragons. Dany shivered. No.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMother to us all. Missandei hugged her tighter. Your Grace should sleep.
2016-07-07 00:50fileClose your eyes. When she did, Dany kissed her eyelids and made her giggle.

2016-07-07 00:50fileDany shut her eyes and tried to think of home, of Dragonstone and Kings Landing and all the other places that Viserys had told her of, in a kinder land than this but her thoughts kept turning back to Slavers Bay, like ships caught in some bitter wind.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Missandei was sound asleep, Dany slipped from her arms and stepped out into the predawn air to lean upon the cool brick parapet and gaze out across the city.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > She found herself thinking of Daario Naharis once again, Daario with his gold tooth and trident beard, his strong hands resting on the hilts of his matched < emphasis > arakh < / emphasis > and stiletto, hilts wrought of gold in the shape of naked women.
2016-07-07 00:50fileShe was a queen, and Daario Naharis was not the stuff of kings.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > It has been so long, she had said to Ser Barristan, just yesterday. What if Daario has betrayed me and gone over to my enemies? < emphasis > Three treasons will you know.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOnly a blind man could believe otherwise, and Daario Naharis was not blind. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan was sure he would return, though.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDany could only pray that he was right.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHear me, Daenerys Targaryen.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > <emphasis > Daenerys.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Dany glanced back toward the persimmon tree.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > She was the blood of the dragon, but Ser Barristan had warned her that in that blood there was a taint.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Missandei returned with a melon and a bowl of hard-cooked eggs, but Dany found she had no appetite.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > In the purple hall, Dany found her ebon bench piled high about with satin pillows.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The freedmen work cheaply because they are hungry, Dany pointed out. If I forbid them to carve stone or lay bricks, the chandlers, the weavers, and the goldsmiths will soon be at my gates asking that they be excluded from those trades as well. She considered a moment. Let it be written that henceforth only guild members shall be permitted to name themselves journeymen or masters
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > So shall it be proclaimed, said Reznak. Will it please Your Worship to hear the noble Hizdahr zo Loraq? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Dany grimaced.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Dany had no answer for that.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan escorted her back up to her chambers. Tell me a tale, ser, Dany said as they climbed. Some tale of valor with a happy ending. She felt in need of happy endings. Tell me how you escaped from the Usurper. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50fileAs I spurred for the gates I heard Janos Slynt shouting for them to go after me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAfterward I went into the Great Sept and thanked the seven gods that Joffrey had stripped me of my cloak. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Inside the cave? suggested Meera. The cave is warded.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I see it, said Bran.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor shifted his weight. Hodor. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A fold in the rock, thats all I see, said Meera. Theres a passage there.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > No, < / emphasis > thought Bran, < emphasis > but all those yards are upward.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBeneath the trees, the ground was blanketed in white, still pristine and unbroken. No ones here, said Bran, bravely. Look at the snow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > The three-eyed crow, < / emphasis > thought Bran.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMaybe we can have a fire. All of them were cold and wet and hungry, except the ranger, and Jojen Reed was too weak to walk unaided.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You go. Meera Reed bent down beside her brother.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMeera had been carrying him all day.

2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Food and fire will set him right again, < / emphasis > Bran tried to tell himself, though he wasnt sure it would. I cant fight and carry Jojen both, the climbs too steep, Meera was saying. Hodor, you take Bran up to that cave. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor. Hodor clapped his hands together. Jojen just needs to eat, Bran said, miserably.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran wept like a little girl when the bright blood came rushing out.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe had never felt more like a cripple than he did then, watching helplessly as Meera Reed and Coldhands butchered the brave beast who had carried them so far.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He needs to eat, Meera agreed, smoothing her brothers brow. We all do, but theres no food here.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bran blinked back a tear and felt it freeze upon his cheek.
2016-07-07 00:50fileColdhands took Hodor by the arm. The light is fading.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Wordless for once, Hodor slapped the snow off his legs, and plowed upward through the snowdrifts with Bran upon his back.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs they climbed, Bran turned awkwardly in his basket to watch as Meera slid an arm beneath her brother to lift him to his feet.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMeera had just begun to struggle up the hill, half-dragging and half-carrying her little brother, when Hodor passed between two trees, and Bran lost sight of them.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe ranger caught him by the arm and saved him. Hodor, said Hodor.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Only eighty yards now, < / emphasis > Bran thought, < emphasis > thats not far at all.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor, stop, said Bran. Hodor.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Coldhands was still climbing, and Hodor wanted to keep up. Hodor, hodor, hodor, he grumbled loudly, to drown out Brans complaints.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHodor was leaning forward, grasping at rocks and trees with his hands as he climbed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe snow Hodor disturbed slid downhill, starting a small avalanche behind them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Bran craned himself sideways to better see the cave.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor screamed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bran felt the world slide sideways as the big stableboy spun violently around.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis mouth was full of blood and Hodor was thrashing and rolling, crushing the crippled boy beneath him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > For half a heartbeat Bran thought maybe a root had gotten tangled round his ankle until the root moved.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor kicked at it, slamming a snow-covered heel full into the things face, but the dead man did not even seem to feel it.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSnow filled Brans mouth and nose as they rolled over, but in a half a heartbeat he was rolling up again.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Bran lost count.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran saw Coldhands slash one across the face.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTwo more were going after Hodor, lumbering clumsily down the slope.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMeera was going to climb right into this, Bran realized, with a sick sense of helpless terror.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran filled a fist with snow and threw it, but the wight did not so much as blink.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran glimpsed skin tear like cheap cloth, heard the splintering of bone.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran rolled away from it.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNo one was paying any mind to Bran.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > And suddenly he was not Bran, the broken boy crawling through the snow, suddenly he was Hodor halfway down the hill, with the wight raking at his eyes.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran ripped Hodors longsword from his belt.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDeep inside he could hear poor Hodor whimpering still, but outside he was seven feet of fury with old iron in his hand.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHe raised the sword and brought it down upon the dead man, grunting as the blade sheared through wet wool and rusted mail and rotted leather, biting deep into the bones and flesh beneath. <emphasis > HODOR!

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bran backed away, bleeding, and Meera Reed was there, driving her frog spear deep into the wights back. Hodor, Bran roared again, waving her uphill. <emphasis > Hodor, hodor.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jojen was twisting feebly where shed laid him down.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran went to him, dropped the longsword, gathered the boy into Hodors arm, and lurched back to his feet. <emphasis > HODOR!
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Meera led the way back up the hill, jabbing at the wights when they came near.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe things could not be hurt, but they were slow and clumsy. Hodor, Hodor said with every step. Hodor, hodor. He wondered what Meera would think if he should suddenly tell her that he loved her.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > The wights, < / emphasis > Bran realized.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Will I be Hodor for good or all?
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe could hear Hodor screaming, Hodor hodor hodor hodor.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHodor hodor hodor hodor.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHodor hodor hodor hodor hodor. A cloud of ravens was pouring from the cave, and he saw a little girl with a torch in hand, darting this way and that.
2016-07-07 00:50fileFor a moment Bran thought it was his sister Arya madly, for he knew his little sister was a thousand leagues away, or dead.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Everything turned inside out and upside down, and Bran found himself back inside his own skin, half-buried in the snow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt was one of the naked ones, Bran saw, in the instant before the nearest tree shook off the snow that covered it and dropped it all down upon his head.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSummer was there, sniffing round him, and Hodor, soaking wet.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMeera cradled Jojens head in her lap.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd the Arya thing stood over them, clutching her torch.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The snow, Bran said. It fell on me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileI pulled you out. Meera nodded at the girl. It was her who saved us, though.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran squinted, to see her better.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt < emphasis > was < / emphasis > a girl, but smaller than Arya, her skin dappled like a does beneath a cloak of leaves.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Who are you? Meera Reed was asking.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bran knew. Shes a child.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Meera said, You speak the Common Tongue now. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Two hundred years? said Meera.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Do you have a name? asked Bran. When I am needing one. She waved her torch toward the black crack in the back wall of the cave. Our way is down.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bran shivered again. The ranger < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The three-eyed crow? asked Meera. The greenseer. And with that she was off, and they had no choice but to follow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMeera helped Bran back up onto Hodors back, though his basket was half-crushed and wet from melting snow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The way was cramped and twisty, and so low that Hodor soon was crouching.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran hunched down as best he could, but even so, the top of his head was soon scraping and bumping against the ceiling.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The child went in front with the torch in hand, her cloak of leaves whispering behind her, but the passage turned so much that Bran soon lost sight of her.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAfter they had gone down a little, the cave divided, but the left branch was dark as pitch, so even Hodor knew to follow the moving torch to the right.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran saw great white snakes slithering in and out of the earth around him, and his heart thumped in fear.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor saw them too. Hodor, he whimpered, reluctant to go on.

2016-07-07 00:50fileBut when the girl child stopped to let them catch her, the torchlight steadied, and Bran realized that the snakes were only white roots like the one hed hit his head on. Its weirwood roots, he said. Remember the heart tree in the godswood, Hodor?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hodor. Hodor plunged ahead, hurrying after the child and her torch, deeper into the earth.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > There were more side passages after that, more chambers, and Bran heard dripping water somewhere to his right.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > All the color is gone, < / emphasis > Bran realized suddenly.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd Bran had never seen so many of them.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs Hodor thumped after her, something crunched beneath his feet.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis halt was so sudden that Meera and Jojen almost slammed into his back.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bones, said Bran. Its bones. The floor of the passage was littered with the bones of birds and beasts.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBran saw a bear skull and a wolf skull, half a dozen human skulls and near as many giants.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHodor made the final descent on his arse, bumping and sliding downward in a clatter of broken bones, loose dirt, and pebbles.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDown below in the darkness, Bran heard the sound of rushing water.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Do we have to cross? Bran asked, as the Reeds came sliding down behind him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf Hodor slipped on that narrow bridge, they would fall and fall.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBehind them Meera gasped.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHodor turned.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > His body was so skeletal and his clothes so rotted that at first Bran took him for another corpse, a dead man propped up so long that the roots had grown over him, under him, and through him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Are you the three-eyed crow? Bran heard himself say.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Bran could feel the eye staring at him, shining like a pool of blood in the torchlight.

2016-07-07 00:50fileBlack of garb and black of blood. The clothes he wore were rotten and faded, spotted with moss and eaten through with worms, but once they had been black. I have been many things, Bran.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Im here, Bran said, only Im broken.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You will never walk again, Bran, the pale lips promised, but you will fly. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > TYRION < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe nights had never been kind to Tyrion Lannister.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion pulled on his boots and descended to the afterdeck, where Griff sat wrapped in a wolf-skin cloak beside an iron brazier.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion squatted across from him and warmed his hands over the coals.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > The river had perils, the dwarf knew, but Griff himself struck Tyrion as more dangerous than any of them.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe reminded Tyrion of Bronn, though Bronn had a sellswords black humor and Griff had no humor at all.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I would kill for a cup of wine, muttered Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion had drunk himself blind his first night on the < emphasis > Shy Maid.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Wine helps me sleep, Tyrion had protested.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion scratched at his scar and tried to recall the authors name.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt was her custom to bathe in the river every morning. Plainly, this boat was not named for you, Tyrion called as she disrobed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When Lemore climbed back onto the deck, Tyrion savored the sight of water trickling between her breasts, her smooth skin glowing golden in the morning light.

2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion had glimpsed a dozen different sorts: large turtles and small ones, flatbacks and red-ears, softshells and bonesnappers, brown turtles, green turtles, black turtles, clawed turtles and horned turtles, turtles whose ridged and patterned shells were covered with whorls of gold and jade and cream.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When Ysilla turned her back, Tyrion snatched a biscuit off the brazier, darting away just in time to avoid a smack from her fearsome wooden spoon.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion waddled over to join him. Now heres a sight to see, he quipped as they were emptying their bladders, a dwarf and a duck, making the mighty Rhoyne that much mightier. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Yandry snorted in derision. Mother Rhoyne has no need of your water, Yollo.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion shook off the last few drops. Big enough to drown a dwarf, I grant you.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion pulled apart two biscuits, filled them with bacon, and carried one to Yandry at the tiller.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You do not know the river, Yollo.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Slave-catchers would be a welcome change from turtles. Not being an escaped slave, Tyrion need not fear being caught.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion helped him dress for the bout, in heavy breeches, padded doublet, and a dinted suit of old steel plate.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion tossed a line to him. Ducks should swim better than that, he said as he and Yandry were hauling the knight back aboard the < emphasis > Shy Maid.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Rolly grabbed Tyrion by the collar. Let us see how dwarfs swim, he said, chucking him headlong into the Rhoyne.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion had taken to it eagerly.
2016-07-07 00:50fileEven Cersei laughed to see him once or twice.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat night at supper Tyrion surprised his sire by walking the length of the high table on his hands.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Tywin was not pleased. The gods made you a dwarf.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > You have a gift for making men smile, Septa Lemore told Tyrion as he was drying off his toes. You should thank the Father Above.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhilst Young Griff went off with Septa Lemore to be instructed in the mysteries of the Faith, Tyrion stripped off the wet clothes and donned dry ones.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGriff had even insisted that Tyrion help with the cutting and sewing.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNo doubt he meant for it to be humbling, but Tyrion enjoyed the needlework.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Somewhere, he knew, Lord Tywin Lannister was horrified, and that took the sting from it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion had read much and more of dragons through the years.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe greater part of those accounts were idle tales and could not be relied on, and the books that Illyrio had provided them were not the ones he might have wished for.

2016-07-07 00:50fileTen years ago, Tyrion had read a fragment of < emphasis > Unnatural History < / emphasis > that had eluded the Blessed Baelor, but he doubted that any of Barths work had found its way across the narrow sea.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHaldon stalked to the stern to piss down at the sun where it shimmered on the water, breaking apart with every puff of wind. We should reach the junction with the Noyne by evening, Yollo, the Halfmaester called out.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion glanced up from his writing. My name is Hugor.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYollo is hiding in my breeches.

2016-07-07 00:50fileYou might frighten the turtles. Haldons smile was as sharp as the blade of a dagger. What did you tell me was the name of that street in Lannisport where you were born, Yollo? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt had no name. Tyrion took a mordant pleasure in inventing the details of the colorful life of Hugor Hill, also known as Yollo, a bastard out of Lannisport.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe Volantene dialect was as new to him as it was to Tyrion, so every day they learned a few more words whilst Haldon corrected their mistakes.

2016-07-07 00:50fileMeereenese was harder; its roots were Valyrian as well, but the tree had been grafted onto the harsh, ugly tongue of Old Ghis. You need a bee up your nose to speak Ghiscari properly, Tyrion complained.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > He has a better ear than me, < / emphasis > Tyrion was forced to admit, < emphasis > though Ill wager my tongue is still more nimble.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThere the boy was less adroit, but Haldon was a patient teacher, and Tyrion was able to make himself of use as well.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > By the time they turned to history, Young Griff was growing restive. We were discussing the history of Volantis, Haldon said to him. Can you tell Yollo the difference between a tiger and an elephant? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > A small garrison in Moat Cailin can play havoc with any army coming up the causeway, but the ruins are vulnerable from the north and east. Jon turned back to Stannis. Sire, this is a bold stroke, but the risk" < emphasis > The Nights Watch takes no part.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > If Roose Bolton should catch you beneath his walls with his main strength, it will be the end for all of you. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Risk is part of war, declared Ser Richard Horpe, a lean knight with a ravaged face whose quilted doublet showed three deaths-head moths on a field of ash and bone. Every battle is a gamble, Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Siege towers can be raised if need be, Stannis said. Trees can be felled for rams if rams are required.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stannis gave him a sour look. Not for me, ser.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > He means to plunder our armory, < / emphasis > Jon realized.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When Donal Noye died we lost our armorer. The rest Jon left unspoken.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > If Stannis placed the free folk in the van, most would perish quickly. Drinking from Mance Rayders skull may give Mors Umber pleasure, but seeing wildlings cross his lands will not.
2016-07-07 00:50fileI must assume they see me as what was it that you called me, Lord Snow?
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Stannis stared at the map.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Snow, remain. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileHorpe followed him out, after giving Jon a measured look.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe last man to take his leave was Rattleshirt.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAt the door, he gave Jon a mocking bow, grinning through a mouthful of brown and broken teeth.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > All of you < / emphasis > did not seem to include Lady Melisandre.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Stannis called to Devan for more lemon water.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe once served my brother Robert as squire and acquired his appetite for female flesh.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHorpe will take Val to wife if I command it, but it is battle he lusts for.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs a squire he dreamed of a white cloak, but Cersei Lannister spoke against him and Robert passed him over.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhich would you have as Lord of Winterfell, Snow?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon said, Winterfell belongs to my sister Sansa. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileYour fathers bannermen would rally to the son of Eddard Stark.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt is not too late to amend your folly, Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTake a knee and swear that bastard sword to me, and rise as Jon Stark, Lord of Winterfell and Warden of the North. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stannis looked disgusted. Your father was a stubborn man as well.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWell, honor has its costs, as Lord Eddard learned to his sorrow.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A northman. < emphasis > Better a Karstark than a Bolton or a Greyjoy, < / emphasis > Jon told himself, but the thought gave him little solace. The Karstarks abandoned my brother amongst his enemies. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He has heirs, Stannis snapped. Two sons, six grandsons, some daughters.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf Robert had fathered trueborn sons, many who are dead might still be living. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Despite the counsel of the great Lord Snow?
2016-07-07 00:50fileI dare not sit idle whilst Roose Boltons star waxes and mine wanes.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The merman of Manderly was not amongst those banners Lady Melisandre saw in her fires, Jon said. If you had White Harbor and Lord Wymans knights < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileWe have had no word from Davos.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNot that Robert ever read one.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon realized that his words were wasted.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis would take the Dreadfort or die in the attempt.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > The Nights Watch takes no part, < / emphasis > a voice said, but another replied, < emphasis > Stannis fights for the realm, the ironmen for thralls and plunder.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I gave you Rattleshirt.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stannis rubbed the back of his neck. You haggle like a crone with a codfish, Lord Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDid Ned Stark father you on some fishwife?
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > With Stannis, it was hard to tell. Done, then.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Youll find them here. Jon spread his burned hand across the map, west of the kingsroad and south of the Gift.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Those mountains? Stannis grew suspicious. I see no castles marked there.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon pulled back his hand. It is no good sending messages.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Could? Stannis missed little. Or will? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50fileOakenfist broke the Planky Town and swept halfway up the Greenblood whilst the main Dornish strength was engaged in the Princes Pass. Stannis drummed his fingers on the map. These mountain lords will not hinder my passage? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon turned to Melisandre. My lady, fair warning.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > That seemed to amuse her. Have no fear, Jon Snow, I will not trouble your mountain savages and their dark gods.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > That was the last thing Jon Snow would have wanted, but before he could object, the king said, Where would you have me lead these stalwarts if not against the Dreadfort? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon glanced down at the map. Deepwood Motte. He tapped it with a finger. If Bolton means to fight the ironmen, so must you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stannis rubbed his jaw. When Balon Greyjoy rose the first time, I beat the ironmen at sea, where they are fiercest.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > And I will have a thousand wildlings, < / emphasis > thought Jon, < emphasis > and no way to feed even half that number.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > TYRION < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I do not like this place, Haldon Halfmaester muttered. Frightened of a little fog? mocked Tyrion, though in truth there was quite a lot of fog.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > This is no common fog, Hugor Hill, Ysilla insisted. It stinks of sorcery, as you would know if you had a nose to smell it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Theres one now, said Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Garins Curse is only greyscale, said Tyrion.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The conquerors did not believe either, Hugor Hill, said Ysilla. The men of Volantis and Valyria hung Garin in a golden cage and made mock as he called upon his Mother to destroy them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Where? Tyrion saw nothing but the fog. Something moved.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Too rich, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion, < emphasis > too beautiful.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Is it wise to shout through the fog at boats we cannot see? asked Tyrion. What if they were pirates? They had been fortunate where the pirates were concerned, slipping down Dagger Lake by night, unseen and unmolested.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIllyrio has paid Triarch Nyessos enough to own him eight times over. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > In gold or cheese? quipped Tyrion.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion still had the poison mushrooms he had plucked from the grounds of Illyrios manse, and there were days when he was sore tempted to slip them into Griffs supper.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > All Tyrion could see was something massive rising from the river, humped and ominous.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe fog concealed three-quarters of the palace, but what they glimpsed was more than enough for Tyrion to know that this island fastness had been ten times the size of the Red Keep once and a hundred times more beautiful.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > There was laughter here once, < / emphasis > Tyrion thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > It was Jaime, < / emphasis > he thought, despairing.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe was Jaime, and you were just some girl whod played a part.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Through the long grey fingers of the fog, he heard again the deep shuddering < emphasis > thrum < / emphasis > of a bowstring snapping taut, the grunt Lord Tywin made as the quarrel took him beneath the belly, the slap of cheeks on stone as he sat back down to die. Wherever whores go, he said.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion wanted to ask him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion saw it too.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Stone eyes are blind eyes, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHacking off afflicted parts did sometimes stop the spread of the disease, Tyrion knew, but not always.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs the < emphasis > Shy Maid < / emphasis > drew closer, Tyrion could see the shapes of stone men moving in the light, shuffling aimlessly around the lamps like slow grey moths.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Aye, said Tyrion, but Im small enough to hide behind a duck. He thrust half a dozen torches into the braziers glowing coals and watched the oiled rags flare up.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Youre a < emphasis > dwarf, < / emphasis > Young Griff said scornfully. My secret is revealed, Tyrion agreed. Aye, Im less than half of Haldon, and no one gives a mummers fart whether I live or die. < emphasis > Least of all me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion clutched his torch tighter and found that he was holding his breath.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion had no sooner exhaled than Young Griff grabbed hold of his arm. What do you mean?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Why, said Tyrion, if the stone men had taken Yandry or Griff or our lovely Lemore, we would have grieved for them and gone on.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAll that remained was a dwindling light astern, and soon enough that would be gone as well. Youre Young Griff, son of Griff the sellsword, said Tyrion. Or perhaps you are the Warrior in mortal guise.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTywin of House Lannister.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf it please Your Grace to call me Yollo or Hugor, so be it, but know that I was born Tyrion of House Lannister, true-born son of Tywin and Joanna, both of whom I slew.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Griff, < / emphasis > is it? The dwarf sniggered. You should thank the gods that Varys the Spider is a part of this plot of yours.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWho better to raise Prince Rhaegars infant son than Prince Rhaegars dear friend Jon Connington, once Lord of Griffins Roost and Hand of the King? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion wondered.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > No, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion, < emphasis > that is not possible.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The Bridge of Dream, said Tyrion. Inconceivable, said Haldon Halfmaester. Weve left the bridge behind.
2016-07-07 00:50fileRivers only run one way. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion felt tendrils brush against his face, soft as a whores fingers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He landed on the cabin roof, so heavily that the < emphasis > Shy Maid < / emphasis > seemed to rock, and roared a word down at them in a tongue that Tyrion did not know.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Two, said Tyrion, shivering. Three, said Haldon. Behind you. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion kicked the lads leg out from under him and leapt over him when he fell, thrusting his torch into the stone mans face to send him stumbling backwards on his shattered leg, flailing at the flames with stiff grey hands.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Bugger me, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat was some small mercy, Tyrion supposed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion drove a shoulder into him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe stone man went over backwards, grabbing hold of Tyrion as he fell.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The sudden cold hit Tyrion like a hammer.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > DAVOS < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos rose. May I know your name, ser? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Marlon Manderly. He was a head taller than Davos and three stones heavier, with slate-grey eyes and a haughty way of speaking. I have the honor to be Lord Wymans cousin and commander of his garrison.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos had come to White Harbor as an envoy, but they had made him a captive.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAs the guards threw open the doors, a herald slammed the butt of his staff against an old plank floor. <emphasis > Ser Davos of House Seaworth, < / emphasis > he called in a ringing voice.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > As many times as he had visited White Harbor, Davos had never set foot inside the New Castle, much less the Mermans Court.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs they approached the dais, Davos trod on painted crabs and clams and starfish, half-hidden amongst twisting black fronds of seaweed and the bones of drowned sailors.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos had hoped to speak with Wyman Manderly alone, but he found a crowded court.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos had learned to read mens faces long before Maester Pylos had taught him to read words on paper.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Gods be good, < / emphasis > thought Davos, when he saw Lord Wymans face, < emphasis > this man looks half a corpse.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > None chose to honor Davos with a name.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The onion knight would have bent his knee, but a Kings Hand could not; to do so would suggest that the king he served was less than this fat lord. I have not come as a petitioner, Davos replied. I have a string of titles too.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis did not like the answer his ravens brought him, so he has sent this this < emphasis > smuggler.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > He squinted at Davos through eyes half-buried in rolls of fat. You have visited our city before, I think, taking coin from our pockets and food off our table.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > I paid for my smuggling at Storms End, my lord. Davos pulled off his glove and held up his left hand, with its four shortened fingers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos did not deny it. If it please my lord, I would request a privy audience. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > My lord, said Davos, I would not want my words to be heard by His Graces enemies or by your lordships. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Not even the men who slew your son? Davos pointed. These Freys were amongst his hosts at the Red Wedding. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The enormity of the lie made Davos gasp. Is it your claim that < emphasis > Robb Stark < / emphasis > killed Wendel Manderly? he asked the Frey.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos wanted to peel his lips off with a knife. Ser, may I have your name? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos misliked the sound of that, but he had not come all this way to hold his tongue. The boy on the Iron Throne is a usurper, he said, and I am no traitor, but the Hand of Stannis Baratheon, the First of His Name, the trueborn King of Westeros. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The fat maester cleared his throat. Stannis Baratheon was brother to our late King Robert, may the Father judge him justly.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTommen is the issue of Roberts body.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A < emphasis > trueborn < / emphasis > son comes before a brother, Davos agreed, but Tommen-called-Baratheon is bastard-born, as his brother Joffrey was before him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis took his thieving fingers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > What would a Frey know of honor? Davos threw back.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Edric Storm, < / emphasis > thought Davos, < emphasis > but I sent him far away across the narrow sea, to keep him safe from Melisandres fires.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > You have the word of Stannis Baratheon that all Ive said is true. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The pink woman pointed a plump finger down at Davos. We want no part of any treason, you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > If White Harbor should declare for Stannis, her husband would answer with his life.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > My lord, said Davos, I pray no harm will come to your son, or to any man of White Harbor. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos thought it best to ignore her. When Robb Stark took up arms against the bastard Joffrey-called-Baratheon, White Harbor marched with him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Robb Stark was my liege lord, said Lord Wyman. Who is this man Stannis?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He came to save the realm, my lord, Davos insisted. To defend your lands against the ironborn and the wildlings. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileDoes Lord Stannis propose to defend us from snarks and dragons too? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Laughter swept the Mermans Court, but at Lord Wymans feet, Lady Leona began to sob. Ironmen from the isles, wildlings from beyond the Wall and now this traitor lord with his outlaws, rebels, and sorcerers. She pointed a finger at Davos. We have heard of your red witch, oh yes.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos had no love for the red priestess, but he dare not let Lady Leona go unanswered. Lady Melisandre is a priestess of the red god.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQueen Selyse has adopted her faith, along with many others, but more of His Graces followers still worship the Seven.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis would not have me lie.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Indeed. Lord Wyman gave Lady Leona a pat on the shoulder. Lord Davos, if you < emphasis > are < / emphasis > a lord, I know what your so-called king would have of me.

2016-07-07 00:50fileSteel and silver and a bended knee. He shifted his weight to lean upon an elbow. Before he was slain, Lord Tywin offered White Harbor full pardon for our support of the Young Wolf.
2016-07-07 00:50fileRoose Bolton, who is named our Warden of the North, requires that I give up my claim to Lord Horn-woods lands and castles but swears my other holdings shall remain untouched.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWalder Frey, his good-father, offers one of his daughters to be my wife, and husbands for my sons daughters here behind me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSo I ask you, Onion Knight" what does Lord Stannis offer me in return for my allegiance? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > War and woe and the screams of burning men, < / emphasis > Davos might have said. The chance to do your duty, he replied instead.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat was the answer Stannis would have given Wyman Manderly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > My lord, said Ser Marlon, in his ornate silver armor, will you permit me to ask a few questions of Lord Davos? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Marlon turned to Davos. How many northern lords have declared for Stannis?
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhat castles does Lord Stannis hold at present, pray? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Marlon went on. How many men can Stannis put into the field, can you tell us that?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Too few, < / emphasis > Davos knew.
2016-07-07 00:50fileStannis had come north with no more than fifteen hundred men but if he told them that, his mission here was doomed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYour king brings us only enemies. Ser Marlon turned to his lord cousin. Your lordship asked the onion knight what Stannis offers us.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDo you have any more to say to me, Onion Knight, or can we put an end to this mummers farce?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Davos felt a stab of despair.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGo to Kings Landing and look on Tommen with your own eyes, if you doubt me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhat does Stannis offer you?

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > It belonged to the half-grown child with the blond eyebrows and the long green braid. They killed Lord Eddard and Lady Catelyn and King Robb, she said. He was our < emphasis > king < / emphasis >!
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf Lord Stannis will avenge him, we should join Lord Stannis. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Rhaegar Frey acknowledged the compliment with a bow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileI hope you will be as loyal to Little Walder when you are joined in wedlock.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ramsay < emphasis > Snow, < / emphasis > Wylla Manderly threw back. Have it as you will.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBy any name, he shall soon be wed to Arya Stark.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A murmur of assent swept the Mermans Court. The maid tells it true, declared a stocky man in white and purple, whose cloak was fastened with a pair of crossed bronze keys. Roose Boltons cold and cunning, aye, but a man can deal with Roose.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > <emphasis > They < / emphasis > say? Rhaegar Frey sported a silky beard and a sardonic smile. His < emphasis > enemies < / emphasis > say, aye but it was the Young Wolf who was the monster.
2016-07-07 00:50fileRobb Stark betrayed us all.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDavos could feel the chill in the air.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Wyman was looking down at Rhaegar as if he were a roach in need of a hard heel yet then, abruptly, he gave a ponderous nod that set his chins to wobbling. A dog, aye.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Rhaegar Frey went on. Grief and death, aye and this onion lord will bring you more with his talk of vengeance.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTommen is our king, our < emphasis > only < / emphasis > king.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > There went my only friend in this hall, < / emphasis > thought Davos.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Rhaegar shrugged. Marriage will soften her, I have no doubt.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > If not, there are the silent sisters. Lord Wyman shifted in his seat. As for you, Onion Knight, I have heard sufficient treason for one day.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYou would have me sacrifice my only living son so Stannis Baratheon can plant his puckered arse upon a throne to which he has no right.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Before Davos could even think to move, he was surrounded by silver tridents. My lord, he said, I am an envoy. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50fileReek picked his way between them carefully, following the remnants of the log-and-plank road that Robb Starks vanguard had laid down across the soft ground to speed the passage of his host.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Robb claimed the Gatehouse Tower for his own.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Robb was at the head of the table, with the Greatjon to his right and Roose Bolton on his left.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > I am here at the command of Ramsay Bolton, Lord of the Hornwood and heir to the Dreadfort, who captured me at Winterfell.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLord Balon bent the knee when Robert broke his wall.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > My uncle is never coming back, Reek told them. The kingswood crowned his brother Euron, and the Crows Eye has other wars to fight.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When the last of them were gone, Ramsay Bolton turned his smile on Reek.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWalder, see to it.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBen, do you have a collar for him? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ill have one made, mlord, said old Ben Bones.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Three days later, the vanguard of Roose Boltons host threaded its way through the ruins and past the row of grisly sentinels" four hundred mounted Freys clad in blue and grey, their spearpoints glittering whenever the sun broke through the clouds.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTwenty thousand swords and spears had gone off to war with Robb, or near enough to make no matter, but only two in ten were coming back, and most of those were Dreadfort men.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > No crannogman will slay Roose Bolton with a poisoned arrow, < / emphasis > Reek thought when he first saw him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Just caution, whispered Roose Bolton, as he emerged from behind the curtains of the enclosed wagon.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThough Roose had been in battles, he bore no scars.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThere was an agelessness about him, a stillness; on Roose Boltons face, rage and joy looked much the same.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Reek wondered if Roose Bolton ever cried.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Once, a boy called Theon Greyjoy had enjoyed tweaking Bolton as they sat at council with Robb Stark, mocking his soft voice and making japes about leeches.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Lord Roose studied him for a moment. You may rise. He turned to help two young women down from inside the wagon.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The first was short and very fat, with a round red face and three chins wobbling beneath a sable hood. My new wife, Roose Bolton said. Lady Walda, this is my natural son.
2016-07-07 00:50fileKiss your stepmothers hand, Ramsay. He did. And I am sure you will recall the Lady Arya.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Arya had her fathers eyes, the grey eyes of the Starks.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJeyne, that was her name.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJeyne Poole.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > The real Arya Stark would have spat into his face.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had fallen asleep over his work again.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSam was right, the books desperately needed to be sorted, listed, and put in order, but that was no task for stewards who could neither read nor write.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon feared for Sam and Maester Aemon.

2016-07-07 00:50fileWhether the broken ship was < emphasis > Blackbird, < / emphasis > one of Stannis Baratheons sellsails, or some passing trader, the crew of the < emphasis > Storm Crow < / emphasis > had not been able to discern.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > I meant to send Gilly and the babe to safety.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDolorous Edd had filled his trencher almost to overflowing to allow Three-Finger Hobbs infamous three-meat stew to soften the stale bread.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bowen Marsh had urged him to move into the Old Bears former chambers in the Kings Tower after Stannis vacated them, but Jon had declined.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A strange listlessness had settled over Castle Black since Stannis had marched south, as if the free folk and the black brothers alike were holding their breath, waiting to see what would come.

I earned my spurs in Dorne.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Jorah claimed a table in a quiet corner and ordered food and drink.
