2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Barristan Selmy refused to believe that Daenerys Targaryen was dead.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJhogo, Daario Naharis, Admiral Groleo, and Hero of the Unsullied remained hostages of the Yunkaii.
2016-07-07 00:50fileEven Missandei had been replaced; the king did not think it fit to use a child as his herald, and a onetime Naathi slave at that.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHizdahr zo Loraq might be his queens consort, but he would never be his king. If His Grace wishes for me to remove myself from court < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Ser Barristan was unsurprised.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHizdahr zo Loraq sat uneasily on his new throne.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHizdahrs blunder with Grey Worm had cost him the Unsullied.

2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen His Grace had tried to put them under the command of a cousin, as he had the Brazen Beasts, Grey Worm had informed the king that they were free men who took commands only from their mother.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSer Barristan took his leave, grateful to leave the stench of the seneschals perfume behind him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > A long climb for a man my age, < / emphasis > Ser Barristan thought, as he started up.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOnly Missandei remained, a forlorn little ghost haunting the queens chambers at the apex of the pyramid.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan walked out onto the terrace.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > The slavers will find some way to blame Daenerys for that as well, < / emphasis > Ser Barristan thought bitterly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan felt very tired, very old.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > I came to bring Daenerys home.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Even Robert.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Ten years ago I would have sensed what Daenerys meant to do.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOf Daenerys Targaryen, no trace had been found.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan knew no more of dragons than the tales every child hears, but he knew Targaryens.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys had been < emphasis > riding < / emphasis > that dragon, as Aegon had once ridden Balerion of old.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan turned. Missandei.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Ser Barristan had hated the masks from the start and never more than now.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > And if Ser Barristan were seen speaking with him, suspicion might fall on the knight as well.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt smelled of deceit, of whispers and lies and plots hatched in the dark, all the things hed hoped to leave behind with the Spider and Lord Littlefinger and their ilk.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBarristan Selmy was not a bookish man, but he had often glanced through the pages of the White Book, where the deeds of his predecessors had been recorded.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Can you find this owl again? he asked Missandei.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > This one understands. Missandei turned as if to go, then paused a moment and said, It is said that the Yunkaii have ringed the city all about with scorpions, to loose iron bolts into the sky should Drogon return. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan had heard that too. It is no simple thing to slay a dragon in the sky.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIn Westeros, many tried to bring down Aegon and his sisters.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Missandei nodded.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Words are wind, though, < / emphasis > Ser Barristan thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Barristan Selmy had known many kings.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe had been born during the troubled reign of Aegon the Unlikely, beloved by the common folk, had received his knighthood at his hands.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIn that same cloak he had stood beside the Iron Throne as madness consumed Jaehaeryss son Aerys.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSome nights, Ser Barristan wondered if he had not done that duty too well.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf he had not gone into Duskendale to rescue Aerys from Lord Darklyns dungeons, the king might well have died there as Tywin Lannister sacked the town.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThen Prince Rhaegar would have ascended the Iron Throne, mayhaps to heal the realm.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Jaehaerys, Aerys, Robert.
2016-07-07 00:50fileRhaegar, who would have been a finer king than any of them.
2016-07-07 00:50filePrincess Elia and the children.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAegon just a babe, Rhaenys with her kitten.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd now Daenerys, his bright shining child queen.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Afternoon brought Ser Barristan a brief respite from his doubts.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys would need protectors her own age about her after he was gone, and Ser Barristan was determined to give her such.
2016-07-07 00:50fileKing Hizdahr has his pit fighters, but Daenerys will have knights.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > But Daenerys Targaryen had never established a proper Queensguard even for herself nor issued any commands in respect to her consort.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Keep it so. It was not unknown for Ser Barristan to walk around at night, to make certain the pyramid was secure.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Have they been fed? Ser Barristan asked. Aye, ser, replied the ape. A sheep apiece. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileSer Barristan made his way past the elephants and the queens silver mare, to the back of the stables.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Then a shadow detached itself from inside an empty stall and became another Brazen Beast, clad in pleated black skirt, greaves, and muscled breastplate. A cat? said Barristan Selmy when he saw the brass beneath the hood.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBelwas and the dragon saved Daenerys.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys wanted it, they could see that.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys gone, Yurkhaz dead.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAll those Daenerys freed will be enslaved again.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGrey Worm will listen to you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Daenerys signed that peace, Ser Barristan said. It is not for us to break it without her leave. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys would want her children protected. What of Hizdahr?
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat is all he needed from Daenerys, all he ever wanted.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > I swore no vows to Hizdahr zo Loraq.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd if I had, he has cast me aside, just as Joffrey did.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > If if what he has to say convinces me if I join with you in this, this I would require your word that no harm would come to Hizdahr zo Loraq until unless it can be proved that he had some part in this. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > The gods of Westeros were far away, yet Ser Barristan Selmy paused for a moment to say a silent prayer, asking the Crone to light his way to wisdom.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I will talk to Grey Worm, he said.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Fifty-four, < / emphasis > Victarion thought sourly when they woke him, < emphasis > and she sails alone.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > But the day before and the day before there had been nothing, and only < emphasis > Headless Jeyne < / emphasis > and < emphasis > Fear < / emphasis > before that, then two more days of empty seas and cloudless skies after Ralf the Limper appeared with the remnants of his squadron.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Storms, Ralf the Limper had muttered when he came crawling to Victarion. Three big storms, and foul winds between.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion had thought the same when he met the first storm a day out of Old Volantis.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > The gods hate kinslayers, < / emphasis > he brooded, < emphasis > elsewise Euron Crows Eye would have died a dozen deaths by my hand.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Victarion had made sacrifice before setting sail, and again in the Stepstones when he split the fleet in three, but perhaps he had said the wrong prayers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When < emphasis > Grief < / emphasis > appeared, Victarion summoned Wulfe One-Ear. I will want words with the Vole.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOne day of such reports was all that Victarion Greyjoy could stomach; he paid the gold price for food and water, though it shamed him, and took his ships back out to sea.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAgainst all that, Victarion had four-and-fifty.
2016-07-07 00:50fileEuron had even braved the Smoking Sea and lived to tell of it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Was it too much to hope that for once Euron had told it true?

2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > If she is all that Euron claims, though < / emphasis > They had heard talk of the beauty of Daenerys Targaryen from the lips of pirates in the Stepstones and fat merchants in Old Volantis.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd Euron had not made Victarion a gift of her; the Crows Eye meant to take her for himself.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThey had sailed too far and lost too much for Victarion to turn west without his prize.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion Greyjoy turned back toward the prow, his gaze sweeping across his fleet.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion had gone ashore a dozen times, hunting fresh meat, and had yet to see a cedar.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The girlish maester Euron had inflicted upon him back in Westeros claimed this place had once been called the Isle of a Hundred Battles, but the men who had fought those battles had all gone to dust centuries ago.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion had forbidden his men to bring any of the demonic creatures aboard ship, yet somehow half his fleet was now infested with them, even his own < emphasis > Iron Victory.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion did not like this sea, nor these endless cloudless skies, nor the blazing sun that beat down on their heads and baked the decks until the boards were hot enough to scorch bare feet.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion missed the grey-green waters of home, with their whitecaps and surges.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe last time Victarion had spent a night ashore, his dreams had been dark and disturbing and when he woke his mouth was full of blood.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > So many drowned men, the Drowned God will be strong there, < / emphasis > Victarion had thought when he chose the island for the three parts of his fleet to join up again.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis brother Aeron might have known, but the Damphair was back on the Iron Islands, preaching against the Crows Eye and his rule.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Yet the captains and kings had cried for Euron at the kingsmoot, choosing him above Victarion and other godly men.
2016-07-07 00:50fileEuron had sliced her tongue out before giving her to him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion did not doubt that the Crows Eye had bedded her as well.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion could talk to the dusky woman.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion had only contempt for such weaklings.

2016-07-07 00:50fileSweep in from the sea and smash them, then take the girl and race for home before the Volantenes descend upon us. Victarion was no craven, but no more was he a fool; he could not defeat three hundred ships with fifty-four. Shell be my wife, and you will be her maid. A maid without a tongue could never let slip any secrets.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He might have said more, but that was when the maester came, rapping at the cabin door as timid as a mouse. Enter, Victarion called out, and bar the door.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Maesters had their uses, but Victarion had nothing but contempt for this Kerwin.

2016-07-07 00:50fileNot long after that Kerwin had come creeping to the captain to complain that four of the crew had dragged him belowdecks and used him as a woman. Here is how you put an end to that, Victarion had told him, slamming a dagger down on the table between them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > My hand is here, Victarion said. Look all you like. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe dusky woman wrinkled her nose at the smell, the maester gagged, and even Victarion himself felt his stomach churn. Cut deeper.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion grunted in approval.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe sight alone would sicken any man. Take that filth and go. Victarion nodded at the dusky woman. She can bind me up. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe maester had suggested that the wound might best be drained up on deck, amidst fresh air and sunlight, but Victarion forbade it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion remembered the fight as if it had been yesterday.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > A scratch from a little kitten, < / emphasis > Victarion told himself afterward.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Instead the wound had festered, until Victarion began to wonder whether Serrys blade had been poisoned.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHe might be using one to poison me, hoping I will let him cut my hand off. The more he thought on it, the more likely it seemed. The Crows Eye gave him to me, wretched creature that he is. Euron had taken Kerwin off Greenshield, where he had been in service to Lord Chester, tending his ravens and teaching his children, or perhaps the other away around.

2016-07-07 00:50fileIt was Euron who insisted he be taken, to keep him from making mischief with his birds. His brother had given him three cages of ravens too, so Kerwin could send back word of their voyaging, but Victarion had forbidden him to loose them.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis brother Aeron would have known, but Aeron had seen the majesty of the Drowned Gods watery halls below the sea before being returned to life.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion had a healthy fear of his god, as all men should, but put his faith in steel.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis men called him the Vole. Lord Captain, he said when Victarion appeared, this is Moqorro.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The wizard was a monster of a man, as tall as Victarion himself and twice as wide, with a belly like a boulder and a tangle of bone-white hair that grew about his face like a lions mane.

2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Burned, < / emphasis > Victarion thought, < emphasis > like a man who has been roasted in the flames until his flesh chars and crisps and falls smoking from his bones.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > If he were ten days in the water, hed be dead, or mad from drinking seawater. Salt water was holy; Aeron Damphair and other priests might bless men with it and swallow a mouthful or two from time to time to strengthen their faith, but no mortal man could drink of the deep sea for days at a time and hope to live. You claim to be a sorcerer? Victarion asked the prisoner.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Victarion had seen such men in foreign cities, tending their sacred fires.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThis one was dressed in faded, salt-stained rags that clung to his thick legs and hung about his torso in tatters but when the captain peered at the rags more closely, it did appear as if they might once have been red. A pink priest, Victarion announced.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion Greyjoy mistrusted laughter.
2016-07-07 00:50fileEuron Crows Eye had oft made mock of him when they were boys.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSo had Aeron, before he had become the Damphair.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTheir mockery oft came disguised as praise, and sometimes Victarion had not even realized he was being mocked.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Victarion was uncertain.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > His brother Euron had his pet wizards.
2016-07-07 00:50filePerhaps the Drowned God meant for Victarion to have one too. Why do you say this man is a wizard? he asked the Vole. I see only a ragged red priest. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > That < emphasis > I < / emphasis > would die? Victarion snorted.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Victarion bellowed. Stand back!
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > No one moved until Victarion seized the sorcerer by the arm and pulled him to the hatchway.
2016-07-07 00:50fileVictarion gave her the back of his good hand and knocked her to the deck. Be quiet, woman.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I have seen you in the nightfires, Victarion Greyjoy.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Victarion bristled. Your nightfires lie.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Come sunset, as the sea turned black as ink and the swollen sun tinted the sky a deep and bloody red, Victarion came back on deck.
2016-07-07 00:50fileShe would not be the first woman Victarion Greyjoy had made a widow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > TYRION < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The healer entered the tent murmuring pleasantries, but one sniff of the foul air and a glance at Yezzan zo Qaggaz put an end to that. The pale mare, the man told Sweets.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > What a surprise, < / emphasis > Tyrion thought.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis shit had turned to brown slime streaked with blood and it fell to Yollo and Penny to wipe his yellow bottom clean.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > We need to flee as well, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Yezzan zo Qaggaz liked to keep his darlings close, so it had fallen to Yollo and Penny and Sweets and his other treasures to attend him when he grew sick.
2016-07-07 00:50fileServing at his nightly banquets, Tyrion had soon learned that Yezzan stood foremost amongst those Yunkish lords who favored honoring the peace with Meereen.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion scratched his scar to keep from laughing. This particular dragon has already evinced a fondness for roast pork.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion was inclined to doubt that.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Some of those ships out on the bay are Qartheen, Tyrion reminded her. Lomas Longstrider saw the walls of Qarth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe lord of suet was already dying from whatever hideous disease he had brought back from Sothoryos, it seemed to Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Penny, come with me. Tyrion opened the tent flap and ushered her out into the heat of a Meereenese morning.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYezzans other slaves had refused to go near the overseer once the cramps began, so it was left to Tyrion to keep him warm and bring him drinks.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion had kept the truth of that from Penny, but she needed to understand how things stood with their master. If Yezzan lives to see the sunrise, Ill be stunned. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Clever as an ox too, < / emphasis > Tyrion recalled.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You do < emphasis > not < / emphasis > tell soldiers what to do, Scar said. Soldiers? Tyrion affected puzzlement. Slaves, is what I see.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion wiped the blood from his split lip with the back of his hand.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > No, < / emphasis > thought Tyrion.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The w-water, said Tyrion, cringing. Not river water, the healer said.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Us? Tyrion exchanged a hopeless glance with Penny. Waters heavy.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion backed away. As you say, master. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bring the pails, Tyrion told Penny.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe went off with the man Morgo to fetch Ser Jorah Mormont from his cage.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > The man is a shell, < / emphasis > Tyrion thought, the first time he saw the big knight beaten.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion was not stricken with that affliction himself, thankfully, but if Mormont murdered Morgo, the other slaves might not draw that distinction. Come, he said, before the knight did something brave and stupid.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Two pails for Penny, two for Tyrion, and four for Ser Jorah, two in either hand.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWearing a collar conferred certain advantages, particularly a gilded collar inscribed with the name of Yezzan zo Qaggaz.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > If anyone had thought to ask him, Tyrion could have told them not to bother.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTo the naked eye the Ghiscari looked more formidable than the Yunkish slave soldiers, but Tyrion nursed doubts.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMost of the Yunkish host drew their drinking water from the Skahazadhan, which Tyrion had known was a very bad idea even before the healers warning.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The fact that there were any good wells at all within a days march of the city only went to prove that Daenerys Targaryen was still an innocent where siegecraft was concerned.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > That was what his lord father would have done, Tyrion did not doubt.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > There was no better place to hear the latest news and rumors than around the well. I know what I saw, an old slave in a rusted iron collar was saying, as Tyrion and Penny shuffled along in the queue, and I saw that dragon ripping off arms and legs, tearing men in half, burning them down to ash and bones.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > In this company, silence was the better part of wisdom, but Tyrion could not help himself. No corpse was found, he said.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion sketched a courtly bow, and refrained from pointing out that one of the pigs was really a dog. The sow I ride is actually my sister.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Daenerys Targaryen had been seated in the owners box beside her Ghiscari king, but Tyrions eyes had been drawn to the knight in the white-and-gold armor behind her.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThough his features were concealed, the dwarf would have known Barristan Selmy anywhere.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Illyrio was right about that much, at least, < / emphasis > he remembered thinking.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe could not imagine Barristan the Bold greeting him with anything but hostility.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJaime had killed a madman.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion had put a quarrel through the groin of his own sire, a man Ser Barristan had known and served for years.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs Daenerys Targaryen was taking wing, Nurse had been clapping irons round their ankles to make certain they would not attempt escape on their way back to their master.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Was there a dragon? Tyrion said with a shrug. All I know is that no dead queens were found. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion did not dispute him.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ghazdor the Great-hearted? Tyrion said, sweetly. Our master Yezzan has often spoken of his wits. What Yezzan had actually said was on the order of, < emphasis > I have more wits in the left cheek of my arse than Ghazdor and his brothers have between them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The mule died, said Tyrion. So did Nurse, poor man.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > They started back, each of the dwarfs carrying two brim-full pails of sweet water and Ser Jorah with two pails in each hand.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > This way, Tyrion said, jerking his head to the right.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > As you wish. Tyrion set the pails of water on the ground, grateful for the halt.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe turned to Ser Jorah. A few more beatings and youll be uglier than I am, Mormont.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Good. Tyrion picked up his pails. This way, then. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > And thats the Wicked Sister. Tyrion nodded in the other direction. Trust me, he said. My way is quicker. He set off, his bells jingling.
2016-07-07 00:50fileShe reminded him of Sansa Stark, the child bride he had wed and lost.
2016-07-07 00:50fileShe is older than Sansa.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > At night Tyrion would oft hear her praying.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Nurses face had given Tyrion his first inkling.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe confusion in his eyes was gone in half a heartbeat, but not before Tyrion grasped what it meant.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > They would have pissed themselves laughing if the lions had been loosed, < / emphasis > Tyrion almost told her.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Were not. Tyrion lowered his pails to the ground.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The Second Sons? A queer smile split Ser Jorahs face. If you think to find help there, you dont know Brown Ben Plumm. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Brown Ben is shrewd, tenacious, not unintelligent but wary.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Sweets will see that they are taken care of, Tyrion lied.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > We havent left the camp. Tyrion picked up his pails.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Water, said Tyrion, if it please you. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion could hear Kings Landing in his voice.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > A serjeant, < / emphasis > Tyrion knew, from the way the other two deferred to him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > These are the dwarfs Ben tried to buy, the serjeant told the spearmen, squinting, but the big one best bring him too.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion moved along.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion went ahead as quick as his stunted legs would allow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTyrion bowed. Captain. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Pails? said Brown Ben Plumm.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd not a word o this, to anyone. When they were gone, he smiled at Tyrion. Come for another game of < emphasis > cyvasse, < / emphasis > Yollo? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe studied Tyrion as a man might study a talking snake. Why are you here? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileInto our very tents. He turned to Ben Plumm. Shall I cut his head off, Captain?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Do be careful with my head, said Tyrion. You dont want to get any of my blood on you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I know you as well, my lord, said Tyrion. Youre less purple and more brown than the Plumms at home, but unless your names a lie, youre a westerman, by blood if not by birth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileA younger son of Viserys Plumm, Id wager.
2016-07-07 00:50fileFickle cunts, the lot of them, and Cersei is the worst. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Brown Ben scratched at his beard. Could deliver you alive and wriggling, then.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ive brought you one. Tyrion jerked a thumb at Mormont. That creature? The bravo laughed. An ugly brute, but scars alone dont make a Second Son. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tyrion rolled his mismatched eyes. Lord Plumm, who are these two friends of yours?
2016-07-07 00:50fileBut it was Jorah Mormont who supplied their names. Inkpots is the company paymaster.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tyrion cleared his throat. You can talk of old times later after I am done explaining why my head would be of more use to you upon my shoulders.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIf you doubt me, ask Bronn.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Might be, said Brown Ben. Or might be you just made up some names.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Stand fast, Jon Snow called. Throw them back. He stood atop the Wall, alone. Flame, he cried, feed them flame, but there was no one to pay heed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileScarecrow brothers tumbled down, black cloaks ablaze. <emphasis > Snow, < / emphasis > an eagle cried, as foemen scuttled up the ice like spiders.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon was armored in black ice, but his blade burned red in his fist.
2016-07-07 00:50fileToo late he recognized Ygritte.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon stabbed and slashed and cut.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQhorin Halfhand stumbled to his knees, trying in vain to staunch the flow of blood from his neck. I < emphasis > am < / emphasis > the Lord of Winterfell, Jon screamed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileIt was Robb before him now, his hair wet with melting snow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThen a gnarled hand seized Jon roughly by the shoulder.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > and woke with a raven pecking at his chest. <emphasis > Snow, < / emphasis > the bird cried.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon swatted at it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon Snow ran his burned hand through his hair and wondered once again what he was doing.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > It should have been the Old Bear to treat with Tormund.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > He rose and dressed in darkness, as Mormonts raven muttered across the room. <emphasis > Corn, < / emphasis > the bird said, and, <emphasis > King, < / emphasis > and, <emphasis > Snow, Jon Snow, Jon Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe bird had never said his full name before, as best Jon could recall.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAs they ate they went over the preparations yet again. All is in readiness, Bowen Marsh assured him. If the wildlings uphold the terms of the bargain, all will go as youve commanded. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Remember, Jon said, Tormunds people are hungry, cold, and fearful.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Last to leave the table was Dolorous Edd Tollett, who had come in during the night with six wagons from the Long Barrow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon watched him mop up a runny yolk with a chunk of bread.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > How do you find serving under Iron Emmett? Jon asked. Mostly its Black Maris serving under him, mlord.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThere was not a wisp of cloud in sight. We have a good day for this, it would seem, Jon said. A bright day, warm and sunny. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon smiled. And if it were to snow? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The sort they keep indoors, said Dolorous Edd. If it please mlord, I should get back to my mules.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > They parted there, Tollett for the east road, where his wagons waited, Jon Snow for the stables.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHe was not the sort of mount that Jon would have chosen for a ranging, but on this morning all that mattered was that he look impressive, and for that the stallion was a perfect choice.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had never liked surrounding himself with guards, but today it seemed prudent to keep a few good men beside him.

2016-07-07 00:50fileFor this Jon had passed over all the green boys and greybeards in his command, choosing eight men in their prime: Ty and Mully, Left Hand Lew, Big Liddle, Rory, Fulk the Flea, Garrett Greenspear.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd Leathers, Castle Blacks new master-at-arms, to show the free folk that even a man who had fought for Mance in the battle beneath the Wall could find a place of honor in the Nights Watch.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > The stars are going out, < / emphasis > Jon thought.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Jon glanced at the Kings Tower, he glimpsed a flash of red behind a window.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOf Queen Selyse he saw no sign.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > It was time. Open the gate, Jon Snow said softly.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDolorous Edd had not been wrong.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon followed, leading his horse.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAfter them came Bowen Marsh and his stewards, a score of them, every man assigned a task.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > North of the Wall, Tormund Giantsbane was waiting, mounted on a runty little garron that looked far too weedy to support his weight.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Tormund called. Guards, is it?
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon peeled the glove off his burned hand, put two fingers in his mouth, and whistled.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTormunds horse shied so hard that the wild-ling almost lost his saddle. Naught to be feared? Jon said. Ghost, stay. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You are a black-hearted bastard, Lord Crow. Tormund Horn-Blower lifted his own warhorn to his lips.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > From dawn till dusk Jon watched the wildlings pass.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The hostages went first" one hundred boys between the ages of eight and sixteen. Your blood price, Lord Crow, Tormund declared. I hope the wailing o their poor mothers dont haunt your dreams at night. Some of the boys were led to the gate by a mother or a father, others by older siblings.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe boys were going to a place that none had ever been before, to serve an order that had been the enemy of their kith and kin for thousands of years, yet Jon saw no tears, heard no wailing mothers.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat was no more than Jon expected.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe saw tall boys and short boys, brown-haired boys and black-haired boys, honey blonds and strawberry blonds and redheads kissed by fire, like Ygritte.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTormund took care to point them out as they went by. The boy there is the son of Soren Shieldbreaker, he said of one tall lad. Him with the red hair, hes Gerrick Kingsbloods get.

2016-07-07 00:50fileThe line o Redbeards little brother, you want it true. Two boys looked enough alike to be twins, but Tormund insisted they were cousins, born a year apart. One was sired by Harle the Huntsman, tother by Harle the Handsome, both on the same woman.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOr so Tormund insisted. They do not look like brothers, Jon observed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Of a certain runty rat-faced boy, Tormund said, That ones a whelp of Varamyr Sixskins.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Jon saw them, he dispatched Rory and Big Liddle to bring them to him.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Are they? Tormund squinted at the pair of them from his saddle. Me and Lord Crow made a wager on which o you has the biggest member.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe other glared defiantly. You leave us alone, Tormund Giantstink.
2016-07-07 00:50fileA spearwife in the making, her. He called to his own men. Go find them something girly to put on before Lord Snow wets his smallclothes. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hows that? Tormund scratched his beard. A hostage is a hostage, seems to me.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Did Mance ever sing of Brave Danny Flint? < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50fileWhat happened to her wasnt. In some versions of the song, her ghost still walked the Nightfort. Ill send the girls to Long Barrow. The only men there were Iron Emmett and Dolorous Edd, both of whom he trusted.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > When nine-and-ninety hostages had shuffled by them to pass beneath the Wall, Tormund Giantsbane produced the last one. My son Dryn.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon gave the boy a close inspection.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Brans age, or the age he would have been if Theon had not killed him.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHe was a chunky boy, with short legs, thick arms, and a wide red face" a miniature version of his father, with a shock of dark brown hair. Hell serve as my own page, Jon promised Tormund.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSee that you dont get above yourself. To Jon he said, Hell need a good beating from time to time.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Five hundred, < / emphasis > Jon Snow judged, as they moved out from beneath the trees, < emphasis > perhaps as many as a thousand.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOthers had armored themselves in bones, like Rattleshirt.

2016-07-07 00:50fileJon could not look at them without remembering Ygritte: the gleam of fire in her hair, the look on her face when shed disrobed for him in the grotto, the sound of her voice. You know nothing, Jon Snow, shed told him a hundred times.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > You might have sent the women first, he said to Tormund. The mothers and the maids. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileA few fighters on tother side, well, that way the gate stays open, dont it? He grinned. I bought your bloody horse, Jon Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon had to smile. So long as they save those weapons for our common foe, I am content. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe word of Tormund Giantsbane.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOthers smiled at him like long-lost kin, though a few of those smiles discomfited Jon Snow more than any glare.
2016-07-07 00:50fileNone knelt, but many gave him their oaths. What Tormund swore, I swear, declared black-haired Brogg, a man of few words.

2016-07-07 00:50fileSoren Shieldbreaker bowed his head an inch and growled, Sorens axe is yours, Jon Snow, if ever you have need of such. Red-bearded Gerrick Kingsblood brought three daughters. They will make fine wives, and give their husbands strong sons of royal blood, he boasted. Like their father, they are descended from Raymun Redbeard, who was King-Beyond-the-Wall. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Blood meant little and less amongst the free folk, Jon knew.
2016-07-07 00:50fileYgritte had taught him that.

2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Three princesses, each lovelier than the last, he told their father. I will see that they are presented to the queen. Selyse Baratheon would take to these three better than she had to Val, he suspected; they were younger and considerably more cowed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Howd Wanderer swore his oath upon his sword, as nicked and pitted a piece of iron as Jon had ever seen.

2016-07-07 00:50fileAmber pendants, golden torques, jeweled daggers, silver brooches set with gem-stones, bracelets, rings, niello cups and golden goblets, warhorns and drinking horns, a green jade comb, a necklace of freshwater pearls all yielded up and noted down by Bowen Marsh.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHow much food such things would buy in the Free Cities, Jon Snow could not begin to say.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon watched a dozen of their big bone chariots roll past him one by one, clattering like Rattleshirt.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOlder children shuffled along behind their mothers and looked up at Jon with eyes as dark and hard as the stones they clutched.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Be wary o that lot, Jon Snow, Tormund warned him. A savage folk.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe men are bad, the women worse. He took a skin off his saddle and offered it up to Jon. Here.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe drank deep. Youre a good man, Tormund Giantsbabe.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon Snow went to have a look for himself.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWith the help of Tormund and his son Toregg, Jon managed to keep the wildlings from coming to blood, but it took the best part of an hour before the way was opened again.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You need a bigger gate, Tormund complained to Jon with a sour look up at the sky, where a few clouds had blown in. Too bloody slow this way.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Did she? Tormund slapped his thigh and hooted. She burned that fine big horn, aye.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThat must have been why Mance got the notion to tell you it were Joramuns.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Jon turned in his saddle, frowning.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > That huge horn with its bands of old gold, incised with ancient runes had Mance Rayder lied to him, or was Tormund lying now?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > By afternoon the sun had gone, and the day turned grey and gusty. A snow sky, Tormund announced grimly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tormund, Jon said, as they watched four old women pull a cartful of children toward the gate, tell me of our foe.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe night that Torwynd my boy, he Tormund turned his face away.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I know, said Jon Snow.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Tormund turned back. You know nothing.
2016-07-07 00:50fileMance killed a hundred.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > We will see, < / emphasis > Jon thought, remembering the things that Sam had told him, the things hed found in his old books.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Dragon-steel, Sam called it.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You are not wrong, Jon said. I do not know.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The gods are seldom good, Jon Snow. Tormund nodded toward the sky. The clouds roll in.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe day grew darker, just as Tormund said.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > It is more than impatience, < / emphasis > Jon realized.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Dance with me, Jon Snow, < / emphasis > he thought.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe soft footing slowed the column even more. You need a bigger gate, Tormund complained again.
2016-07-07 00:50fileColumns of smoke rose from the trees where their camp had been. Toregg, Tormund explained. Burning the dead.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWith him rode a dozen mounted warriors armed with spears and swords. My rear guard, Tormund said, with a gap-toothed smile. You crows have rangers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > A boar, < / emphasis > Jon saw.
2016-07-07 00:50fileJon had never seen a boar so huge or ugly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Borroq. Tormund turned his head and spat. A skinchanger. It was not a question.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe padded out in front of Jon, his teeth bared in a silent snarl.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon snapped. Ghost, down.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Boars and wolves, said Tormund. Best keep that beast o yours locked up tonight.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You go ahead, Jon told him. I mean to be the last one through the ice.
2016-07-07 00:50fileBowen Marsh stayed long enough to supervise as his stewards pulled the last carts into the tunnel.
2016-07-07 00:50fileOnly Jon Snow and his guards were left.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHe gave a snort and lowered his head, and for half a heartbeat Jon thought he was about to charge.
2016-07-07 00:50fileTheyre coming, crow. He smiled as ugly a smile as Jon had ever seen and made his way to the gate.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > No, < / emphasis > thought Jon Snow, < emphasis > it has only just begun.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Bowen Marsh was waiting for him south of the Wall, with a tablet full of numbers. Three thousand one hundred and nineteen wildlings passed through the gate today, the Lord Steward told him. Sixty of your hostages were sent off to Eastwatch and the Shadow Tower after theyd been fed.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Not for long, Jon promised him. Tormund means to lead his own folk to Oakenshield within a day or two.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe tone suggested that Bowen Marsh knew where < emphasis > he < / emphasis > would put them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The castle Jon returned to was far different from the one hed left that morning.
2016-07-07 00:50fileLights now shone through windows where Jon Snow had never seen lights shine before.

2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > Playing, < / emphasis > Jon thought in astonishment, < emphasis > grown men playing like children, throwing snowballs the way Bran and Arya once did, and Robb and me before them.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Send him in. Jon lit a taper from an ember in his brazier and three candles from the taper.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > You did well. Jon read: < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jon Snow rolled up the parchment, frowning.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > A<emphasis > ll kneel for His Magnificence Hizdahr zo Loraq, Fourteenth of That Noble Name, King of Meereen, Scion of Ghis, Octarch of the Old Empire, Master of the Skahazadhan, Consort to Dragons and Blood of the Harpy, < / emphasis > roared the herald.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan Selmy slipped a hand beneath the fold of his cloak and loosened his sword in its scabbard.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Daenerys Targaryen had preferred to hold court from a bench of polished ebony, smooth and simple, covered with the cushions that Ser Barristan had found to make her more comfortable.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > The important throne, < / emphasis > thought Ser Barristan.
2016-07-07 00:50fileThe older he got, the less sleep Ser Barristan seemed to need.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The hall was as crowded as the old knight had ever seen it, but it was the missing faces that Barristan Selmy noted most: Missandei, Belwas, Grey Worm, Aggo and Jhogo and Rakharo, Irri and Jhiqui, Daario Naharis.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > No, no, no, Reznak screeched. Queen Daenerys will return to Meereen in her own time in all her might and majesty.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQueen Daenerys shall be found. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan let Reznaks oily words wash over him.
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys was his only friend at this court, and she is gone.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Prince Quentyn was listening intently, at least.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAnd Daenerys Targaryen, whatever else she might be, was still a young girl, as she herself would claim when it pleased her to play the innocent.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen he saw the prince, Hizdahr zo Loraq frowned.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan did not like that frown.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > I swore no oath to Dorne, < / emphasis > Ser Barristan told himself.

2016-07-07 00:50fileHis continued presence, even after Daenerys had given herself to another before the eyes of gods and men, would provoke any husband, and Quentyn no longer had the queen to shield him from Hizdahrs wroth.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQuentyn had grown up amongst the courts of Dorne.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Daenerys had taken another for her consort, but if Hizdahr died, she would be free to wed again.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWho can say that the locusts were meant for Daenerys?
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys might have had no better choice than Quentyn and his marriage pact.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan was still wrestling with that suspicion when he heard the sound of heavy boots ascending the steep stone steps at the back of the hall.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > No Brown Ben Plumm.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Ser Barristan eyed Bloodbeard coolly.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan glanced toward the throne.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAerys would have flinched away in horror, likely cutting himself on the barbs of the Iron Throne, then shrieked at his swordsmen to cut the Yunkishmen to pieces.
2016-07-07 00:50fileRobert would have shouted for his hammer to repay Bloodbeard in kind.
2016-07-07 00:50fileSer Barristan could smell the seneschals heavy floral perfume from several yards away.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Barristan Selmy was no stranger to severed heads.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Jhogo, Hero, and Daario Naharis all commanded fighting men, but Groleo had been an admiral without a fleet.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Your Grace, Ser Barristan called out. If it please you to recall, the noble Yurkhaz died by happenstance.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hizdahr zo Loraq could not seem to look away from the head.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Sister, said Hizdahr zo Loraq, stiffly. Cousins. He gestured at the bleeding head. Remove that from our sight. < / p >

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The admiral was a man of the sea, Ser Barristan reminded him. Mayhaps Your Magnificence might ask the Yunkaii to return his body to us, so we may bury him beneath the waves? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Reznak mo Reznak cleared his throat noisily. Meaning no offense, yet it seems to me that Her Worship Queen Daenerys gave you ah seven hostages.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Reznak replied. Her Magnificence Queen Daenerys is Mother of Dragons.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan never once took his eyes off Bloodbeard.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hizdahr zo Loraq rose slowly from his dragon throne. I must consult my council.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > <emphasis > All kneel for His Magnificence Hizdahr zo Loraq, Fourteenth of That Ancient Name, King of Meereen, Scion of Ghis, Octarch of the Old Empire, Master of the Skahazadhan, Consort to Dragons and Blood of the Harpy, < / emphasis > the herald shouted.
2016-07-07 00:50fileAs befit his rank and station, Quentyn Martell had been given quarters within the Great Pyramid, two levels down" a handsome suite of rooms with its own privy and walled terrace.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Ser Barristan watched them, thoughtful.
2016-07-07 00:50file< emphasis > What would Daenerys want?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Prince Quentyn, Selmy called. Might I beg a word? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn Martell turned. Ser Barristan.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > It is not my place to counsel you, Prince Quentyn but if I were you, I would not return to my chambers.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Prince Quentyn stared. Leave the pyramid? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Swords can be replaced, said Ser Barristan. I can provide you with coin enough for passage back to Dorne.
2016-07-07 00:50filePrince Quentyn, the king made note of you today.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Gerris Drinkwater laughed. Should we be frightened of Hizdahr zo Loraq?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn Martell nodded in agreement. A prince does well to think before he acts.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Prince Quentyn flushed. The marriage pact" < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileYour father keeps his secrets well, Prince Quentyn.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > That is not for you to judge. Ser Barristan paused, wondering if he had said too much already.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > The shock was plain on Prince Quentyns face. Poison meant for Daenerys? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn Martell went pale. <emphasis > Me?
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Others might, said Ser Barristan. The Red Viper was your uncle.

2016-07-07 00:50file< p > paramour, Ser Barristan finished, before the Dornish knight could say anything that might besmirch the queens honor. That is what you call them down in Dorne, is it not? He did not wait for a reply. Prince Lewyn was my Sworn Brother.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > No, said Quentyn, red-faced, but < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Daario would kill Hizdahr in a heartbeat if he dared, Ser Barristan went on. But not with poison.

2016-07-07 00:50fileIn a few more days, if the gods smiled on them, Hizdahr zo Loraq would no longer rule Meereen but no good would be served by having Prince Quentyn caught up in the bloodbath that was coming. If you must remain in Meereen, you would do well to stay away from court and hope Hizdahr forgets you, Ser Barristan finished, but a ship for Volantis would be wiser, my prince.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Before he had gone three steps, Quentyn Martell called out to him. Barristan the Bold, they call you. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > What name do you think they will give me, should I return to Dorne without Daenerys? Prince Quentyn asked. Quentyn the Cautious?
2016-07-07 00:50fileQuentyn the Craven?
2016-07-07 00:50fileQuentyn the Quail? < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Let him think what he wants, so long as he delivers the message, said Quentyn.
2016-07-07 00:50fileWhen Barristan the Bold tells you to run, a wise man laces up his boots.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > Volantis, < / emphasis > Quentyn thought.
2016-07-07 00:50fileHis father would speak no word of rebuke, Quentyn knew, but the disappointment would be there in his eyes.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > I will not keep you here, Quentyn told his friends. My father laid this task on me, not you.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Agreed, said Quentyn. Arch and Gerris will be with me.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQuentyn and Gerris wore their sword belts.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > No, Prince Quentyn said, but he likes gold. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn frowned. His name was Harghaz. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Hizdahr, said Quentyn. His name is Hizdahr. < / p >
2016-07-07 00:50fileDaenerys is the means to the prize, not the prize itself.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > All dead, Quentyn agreed. For what?
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn looked at the body with distaste. He died of the flux.
2016-07-07 00:50fileQuentyn knocked twice, as instructed.
2016-07-07 00:50fileGerris entered first, for cautions sake, with Quentyn close behind him and the big man bringing up the rear.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > Quentyn saw no sign of the men they had come to meet.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > It was a long way down, and so dark that Quentyn had to feel his way to keep from slipping.
2016-07-07 00:50file< p > < emphasis > One too many, < / emphasis > Quentyn thought.
2016-07-07 00:50file< / emphasis > Quentyn approached his table. My lord.
